comment_text.mn108:2.1: As to the politics of the situation, Pajjota had established a formidable set of alliances by marriage. He had taken to wife Śivā, daughter of Ceṭaka of the Licchavīs. Prince Bodhi of the Bhaggas was Pajjota’s grandson via his mother Vāsuladattā, queen of the powerful King Udena of Kosambī (MN 85:2.1). Meanwhile, Subāhu of Madhurā had married Pajjota’s sister (MN 84:2.1). Pajjota therefore had allies in Avanti, Bhagga, Vaccha, and Sūrasena, all nations to the west of Magadha, as well as Vajjī, against which Magadha was preparing war to the north. He was also friendly enough with Ajātasattu’s father Bimbisāra to ask him for help in a time of illness (Kd 8:1.23.4). The Vinaya relates how Pajjota’s illness was treated by Jīvaka, the doctor of the Buddha and of Bimbisāra. Jīvaka, knowing Pajjota would dislike the medicine, escaped his wrath by fleeing after administering the cure. But when the cure worked, Pajjota favored Jīvaka with a gift of fine cloth. Ajātasattu subsequently murdered Bimbisāra and threatened Pajjota’s allies in Vajjī. Racked by guilt, Ajātasattu saw enemies on all sides; he was even afraid of mendicants meditating in a hall (DN 2:10.8). His fear of Pajjota was not idle, for Pajjota was known for the power of his elephants as much as for his temperamental character. However, we do not hear that any direct conflict flared up at that time. Roughly half a century later, the matter was settled when the Licchavī Śiśunāga, having usurped the throne of Magadha from the Haryaṅka dynasty founded by Bimbisāra, conquered Avanti, Kosala, and Vaccha.
comment_text.mn108:5.3: This links back to the Buddha’s claim in the previous sutta that he is the one who shows the way (MN 107:14.28).
comment_text.mn108:6.2: Vassakāra must have returned from building Pāṭaliputta to the north on the Ganges, which would eventually become the capital of the expanded Magadhan empire (DN 16:1.26.1). | Rājagaha is surrounded by hills, on which remnants of ancient fortifications can be seen.
comment_text.mn108:7.2: Accept reading paṭidhāveyyāthāti (BJT, PTS, Siamese and Khmer editions) against Mahāsaṅgīti’s paṭipādeyyāthāti. For this term, see MN 38:23.4 and note there, and SN 12.20:5.1.
comment_text.mn108:7.3: The Buddha made this clear to Ānanda shortly before his death (DN 16:2.24.4).
comment_text.mn108:8.1: The Vinaya sets up procedures whereby the Saṅgha can appoint officials to carry out necessary duties. For example, a monk might be in charge of assigning dwellings (Bu Ss 8:1.1.1) or teaching the novices (Kd 16:21.3.30). Such officials have authority within the roles prescribed to them under the Vinaya as implemented by the Saṅgha. However, they have no special authority outside of that role, and there is no provision for a general role of authority over the Saṅgha as a whole. The Saṅgha followed this precedent at the First Council, where Ānanda was appointed to recite the suttas, and Upāli to recite the Vinaya. Mahākassapa led the proceedings, but decisions were made by the Saṅgha in consensus.
comment_text.mn108:9.1: The Buddha had, not long before, taught Vassakāra the eight principles of non-decline by which the Vajjis—as well as the Saṅgha—remained strong due to harmony. There, Vassakāra pointedly said that the Vajjis could only be defeated “by bribery or by sowing dissension” (DN 16:1.5.8). Here he returns to the question of how harmony creates strength. We can imagine that this question was equally relevant in both weakening their enemies as well as strengthening the Magadhans, who cannot have been happy to live under their brutal and patricidal king.
comment_text.mn108:9.4: As explained to Ānanda at DN 16:4.7.3. As will become clear, the “teaching” here includes the Dhamma and Vinaya.
comment_text.mn108:10.14: This is the pātimokkha, which in early days had “over a hundred and fifty rules” and today, in the Pali, has 227 for monks (AN 3.84:1.3). The story of how the Buddha came to lay down the first rule is related in the Vinaya (Bu Pj 1). Before this, however, the joint recitation consisted of the verses known as Ovāda Pātimokkha (DN 14:3.28.1). See too DN 2:42.1 and note there. The primary purpose of the recitation was to create a unified community through shared allegiance to a particular code of ethics.
comment_text.mn108:10.15: The “sabbath” (uposatha) falls on the eighth and fourteenth or fifteenth days of the lunar cycle, that is, roughly each week. However the pātimokkha is recited only twice a month, leaving aside the eighth days. See the detailed account in the Vinaya (Kd 2). | A “village district” (gāmakhetta) is the village and surrounding farmlands. The Vinaya account specifies how to create a “boundary” (sīmā) within which all resident mendicants must attend. This may or may not correspond with the village district. But it seems reasonable to suppose that the common practice was, in fact, for mendicants from the same village district to join together.
comment_text.mn108:10.16: The choice of the verb pavattati (“transmits, rolls forth”) is deliberate. It echoes the first sermon, where the Buddha “rolled forth” the wheel of the Dhamma. All mendicants are supposed to memorize the rules and be ready to recite them when called upon. The commentary explains the phrase as “arrives having rehearsed”.
comment_text.mn108:10.17: Offences should be confessed as soon as practicable, but if they have not been previously confessed due to lapse of memory and the like, the recitation may be interrupted to confess them. These days, mendicants normally confess before the recitation to avoid interruptions.
comment_text.mn108:10.19: The Saṅgha proceeds according to the guidelines of the Dhamma and Vinaya, rather than the authority of any individuals. This is again in accordance with some of the Buddha’s final words to Ānanda: “The teaching and training that I have taught and pointed out for you shall be your Teacher after my passing” (DN 16:6.1.1).
comment_text.mn108:11.2: The Mahāsaṅgīti and BJT editions read natthi here (“there is not”). The PTS edition reads atthi (“there is”). The commentary is silent, and none of these editions record any variants. I suspect the PTS edition has amended the text to create a contrast between the “single mendicant” who is respected and the one who is taken as refuge. But the contrast per the MS and BJT editions, rather, is between respecting a “single mendicant”, and respecting “whoever” has the qualities that make them worthy of respect.
comment_text.mn108:13.1: The ten things are ethics, learning, contentment, absorption, and the six direct knowledges. While all of these are taught often in the suttas, I do not think we find this exact set elsewhere.
comment_text.mn108:23.3: The suttas record many monks and nuns of such qualities.
comment_text.mn108:24.1: This Upananda does not appear elsewhere and the commentary is silent.
comment_text.mn108:24.2: Accept the punctuation in Mahāsaṅgīti rather than PTS.
comment_text.mn108:25.5: Ānanda graciously recognizes the protection offered by the Magadhan state. Even a morally compromised king such as Ajātasattu honored his duty to protect religious seekers (DN 2:36.2).
comment_text.mn108:25.6: “Habit of meditating” is jhānasīlī. Throughout this passage, “meditation” renders jhāna. This is the only sutta that speaks of a kind of jhāna with hindrances. My choice to render the term differently in this passage was prefigured by the translator of the Chinese parallel, which here uses the character that normally renders vicāra (MA 145 at T i 655b23).
comment_text.mn108:28.1: Normally, of course, when the Buddha teaches “meditation” he means the kind of meditation he praises, namely the four jhānas, or “absorptions”.
comment_text.mn108:29.4: The Chinese parallel differs here, emphasizing instead that there is no difference between the liberation of the Buddha and his arahant disciples (MA 145 at T i 655c27).
comment_text.mn108:29.6: Ānanda is clarifying that his original statement was complete, namely, this is the quality that distinguishes the Buddha from his followers. | The Pali lacks the normal ending, whereas the Chinese ends with Moggallāna inviting Ānanda for a meal.

root_text.mn108:4.8: Nisīdi kho āyasmā ānando paññatte āsane.

root_text.mn108:4.10: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho gopakamoggallāno brāhmaṇo āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn108:5.1: “atthi nu kho, bho ānanda, ekabhikkhupi tehi dhammehi sabbenasabbaṁ sabbathāsabbaṁ samannāgato yehi dhammehi samannāgato so bhavaṁ gotamo ahosi arahaṁ sammāsambuddho”ti?
root_text.mn108:5.2: “Natthi kho, brāhmaṇa, ekabhikkhupi tehi dhammehi sabbenasabbaṁ sabbathāsabbaṁ samannāgato yehi dhammehi samannāgato so bhagavā ahosi arahaṁ sammāsambuddho.
root_text.mn108:5.3: So hi, brāhmaṇa, bhagavā anuppannassa maggassa uppādetā, asañjātassa maggassa sañjanetā, anakkhātassa maggassa akkhātā, maggaññū, maggavidū, maggakovido;
root_text.mn108:5.4: maggānugā ca pana etarahi sāvakā viharanti pacchā samannāgatā”ti.
root_text.mn108:6.1: Ayañca hidaṁ āyasmato ānandassa gopakamoggallānena brāhmaṇena saddhiṁ antarākathā vippakatā ahosi.
root_text.mn108:6.2: Atha kho vassakāro brāhmaṇo magadhamahāmatto rājagahe kammante anusaññāyamāno yena gopakamoggallānassa brāhmaṇassa kammanto, yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.mn108:6.3: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho vassakāro brāhmaṇo magadhamahāmatto āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn108:6.4: “kāya nuttha, bho ānanda, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
root_text.mn108:6.6: ‘atthi nu kho, bho ānanda, ekabhikkhupi tehi dhammehi sabbenasabbaṁ sabbathāsabbaṁ samannāgato yehi dhammehi samannāgato so bhavaṁ gotamo ahosi arahaṁ sammāsambuddho’ti.

root_text.mn108:24.2: “Taṁ kiṁ maññati bhavaṁ senāpati yadime bhonto sakkātabbaṁ sakkaronti, garuṁ kātabbaṁ garuṁ karonti,
root_text.mn108:24.4: “Tagghime bhonto sakkātabbaṁ sakkaronti, garuṁ kātabbaṁ garuṁ karonti, mānetabbaṁ mānenti, pūjetabbaṁ pūjenti.
root_text.mn108:24.5: Imañca hi te bhonto na sakkareyyuṁ na garuṁ kareyyuṁ na māneyyuṁ na pūjeyyuṁ;
root_text.mn108:24.6: atha kiñcarahi te bhonto sakkareyyuṁ garuṁ kareyyuṁ māneyyuṁ pūjeyyuṁ, sakkatvā garuṁ katvā mānetvā pūjetvā upanissāya vihareyyun”ti?
root_text.mn108:25.1: Atha kho vassakāro brāhmaṇo magadhamahāmatto āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn108:25.4: “Kacci pana, bho ānanda, veḷuvanaṁ ramaṇīyañceva appasaddañca appanigghosañca vijanavātaṁ manussarāhasseyyakaṁ paṭisallānasāruppan”ti?
root_text.mn108:25.5: “Taggha, brāhmaṇa, veḷuvanaṁ ramaṇīyañceva appasaddañca appanigghosañca vijanavātaṁ manussarāhasseyyakaṁ paṭisallānasāruppaṁ, yathā taṁ tumhādisehi rakkhakehi gopakehī”ti.
root_text.mn108:25.6: “Taggha, bho ānanda, veḷuvanaṁ ramaṇīyañceva appasaddañca appanigghosañca vijanavātaṁ manussarāhasseyyakaṁ paṭisallānasāruppaṁ, yathā taṁ bhavantehi jhāyīhi jhānasīlīhi.
root_text.mn108:25.8: Ekamidāhaṁ, bho ānanda, samayaṁ so bhavaṁ gotamo vesāliyaṁ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṁ.
root_text.mn108:25.9: Atha khvāhaṁ, bho ānanda, yena mahāvanaṁ kūṭāgārasālā yena so bhavaṁ gotamo tenupasaṅkamiṁ.
root_text.mn108:25.10: Tatra ca pana so bhavaṁ gotamo anekapariyāyena jhānakathaṁ kathesi.
root_text.mn108:25.11: Jhāyī ceva so bhavaṁ gotamo ahosi jhānasīlī ca.
root_text.mn108:25.12: Sabbañca pana so bhavaṁ gotamo jhānaṁ vaṇṇesī”ti.
root_text.mn108:26.1: “Na ca kho, brāhmaṇa, so bhagavā sabbaṁ jhānaṁ vaṇṇesi, napi so bhagavā sabbaṁ jhānaṁ na vaṇṇesīti.
root_text.mn108:26.2: Kathaṁ rūpañca, brāhmaṇa, so bhagavā jhānaṁ na vaṇṇesi?
root_text.mn108:26.3: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco kāmarāgapariyuṭṭhitena cetasā viharati kāmarāgaparetena, uppannassa ca kāmarāgassa nissaraṇaṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti;
root_text.mn108:26.4: so kāmarāgaṁyeva antaraṁ karitvā jhāyati pajjhāyati nijjhāyati apajjhāyati.
root_text.mn108:26.5: Byāpādapariyuṭṭhitena cetasā viharati byāpādaparetena, uppannassa ca byāpādassa nissaraṇaṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti;
root_text.mn108:26.6: so byāpādaṁyeva antaraṁ karitvā jhāyati pajjhāyati nijjhāyati apajjhāyati.
root_text.mn108:26.7: Thinamiddhapariyuṭṭhitena cetasā viharati thinamiddhaparetena, uppannassa ca thinamiddhassa nissaraṇaṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti;
root_text.mn108:26.8: so thinamiddhaṁyeva antaraṁ karitvā jhāyati pajjhāyati nijjhāyati apajjhāyati.
root_text.mn108:26.9: Uddhaccakukkuccapariyuṭṭhitena cetasā viharati uddhaccakukkuccaparetena, uppannassa ca uddhaccakukkuccassa nissaraṇaṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti;
root_text.mn108:26.10: so uddhaccakukkuccaṁyeva antaraṁ karitvā jhāyati pajjhāyati nijjhāyati apajjhāyati.
root_text.mn108:26.11: Vicikicchāpariyuṭṭhitena cetasā viharati vicikicchāparetena, uppannāya ca vicikicchāya nissaraṇaṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti;
root_text.mn108:26.12: so vicikicchaṁyeva antaraṁ karitvā jhāyati pajjhāyati nijjhāyati apajjhāyati.
root_text.mn108:26.13: Evarūpaṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, so bhagavā jhānaṁ na vaṇṇesi.
root_text.mn108:27.1: Kathaṁ rūpañca, brāhmaṇa, so bhagavā jhānaṁ vaṇṇesi?
root_text.mn108:27.2: Idha, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn108:27.3: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …
root_text.mn108:27.6: Evarūpaṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, so bhagavā jhānaṁ vaṇṇesī”ti.
root_text.mn108:28.1: “Gārayhaṁ kira, bho ānanda, so bhavaṁ gotamo jhānaṁ garahi, pāsaṁsaṁ pasaṁsi.
root_text.mn108:28.2: Handa ca dāni mayaṁ, bho ānanda, gacchāma;
root_text.mn108:28.5: Atha kho vassakāro brāhmaṇo magadhamahāmatto āyasmato ānandassa bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
root_text.mn108:29.1: Atha kho gopakamoggallāno brāhmaṇo acirapakkante vassakāre brāhmaṇe magadhamahāmatte āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn108:29.2: “yaṁ no mayaṁ bhavantaṁ ānandaṁ apucchimhā taṁ no bhavaṁ ānando na byākāsī”ti.
root_text.mn108:29.4: ‘natthi kho, brāhmaṇa, ekabhikkhupi tehi dhammehi sabbenasabbaṁ sabbathāsabbaṁ samannāgato yehi dhammehi samannāgato so bhagavā ahosi arahaṁ sammāsambuddho.
root_text.mn108:29.5: So hi, brāhmaṇa, bhagavā anuppannassa maggassa uppādetā, asañjātassa maggassa sañjanetā, anakkhātassa maggassa akkhātā, maggaññū, maggavidū, maggakovido.
root_text.mn108:29.6: Maggānugā ca pana etarahi sāvakā viharanti pacchā samannāgatā’”ti.

translation_text.mn108:1.2: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground. It was not long after the Buddha had become fully quenched.
translation_text.mn108:2.1: Now at that time King Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha, being suspicious of King Pajjota, was having Rājagaha fortified.
translation_text.mn108:3.1: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Rājagaha for alms.
translation_text.mn108:3.3: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Rājagaha.
translation_text.mn108:3.4: Why don’t I go to see the brahmin Moggallāna the Guardian at his place of work?”
translation_text.mn108:4.2: Moggallāna the Guardian saw Ānanda coming off in the distance
translation_text.mn108:4.6: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.
translation_text.mn108:4.7: Please, sir, sit down, this seat is ready.”
translation_text.mn108:4.8: Ānanda sat down on the seat spread out,
translation_text.mn108:4.9: while Moggallāna took a low seat and sat to one side.
translation_text.mn108:5.1: “Worthy Ānanda, is there even a single mendicant who has all the same qualities in each and every way as possessed by the worthy Gotama, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
translation_text.mn108:5.3: For the Blessed One gave rise to the unarisen path, gave birth to the unborn path, and explained the unexplained path. He is the knower of the path, the discoverer of the path, the expert on the path.
translation_text.mn108:5.4: And now the disciples live following the path; they acquire it later.”
translation_text.mn108:6.1: But this conversation between Ānanda and Moggallāna the Guardian was left unfinished.
translation_text.mn108:6.2: For just then the brahmin Vassakāra, a minister of Magadha, while supervising the work at Rājagaha, approached Ānanda at Moggallāna’s place of work and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn108:6.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Ānanda,
translation_text.mn108:6.4: “Worthy Ānanda, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
translation_text.mn108:6.5: So Ānanda told him of the conversation that they were having when Vassakāra arrived. Vassakāra said:
translation_text.mn108:7.1: “Worthy Ānanda, is there even a single mendicant who was appointed by the worthy Gotama, saying:
translation_text.mn108:7.2: ‘This one will be your refuge when I have passed away,’ to whom you would now turn?”
translation_text.mn108:8.1: “But is there even a single mendicant who has been elected to such a position by the Saṅgha and appointed by several senior mendicants?”
translation_text.mn108:9.1: “But since you lack a refuge, worthy Ānanda, what’s the reason for your harmony?”
translation_text.mn108:10.1: “But worthy Ānanda, when asked whether there was even a single mendicant—either appointed by the Buddha,
translation_text.mn108:10.5: or elected by the Saṅgha and appointed by several senior mendicants—
translation_text.mn108:10.6: who serves as your refuge after the Buddha passed away, to whom you now turn,
translation_text.mn108:10.10: But you say that the reason for your harmony is that you have
translation_text.mn108:10.13: How should I see the meaning of this statement?”
translation_text.mn108:10.14: “The Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha laid down training rules and recited the monastic code for the mendicants.
translation_text.mn108:10.15: On the day of the sabbath all of us who live in dependence on one village district gather together as one.
translation_text.mn108:10.16: We invite one who transmits the code to recite it.
translation_text.mn108:10.17: If anyone remembers an offense or transgression while they’re reciting, we make them act in line with the teaching and in line with the instructions.
translation_text.mn108:10.18: It’s not the good fellows who make us act,
translation_text.mn108:10.19: it’s the teaching that makes us act.”
translation_text.mn108:11.1: “Worthy Ānanda, is there even a single mendicant who you honor, respect, revere, venerate, and rely on?”
translation_text.mn108:11.3: “Worthy Ānanda, when asked whether there was even a single mendicant—either appointed by the Buddha,
translation_text.mn108:12.2: or elected by the Saṅgha and appointed by several senior mendicants—
translation_text.mn108:12.3: who serves as your refuge after the Buddha passed away, to whom you now turn,
translation_text.mn108:12.6: And when asked whether there is even a single mendicant who you honor, respect, revere, venerate, and rely on,
translation_text.mn108:12.8: How should I see the meaning of this statement?”
translation_text.mn108:13.1: “There are ten inspiring things explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn108:13.2: We honor anyone in whom these things are found.
translation_text.mn108:14.1: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
translation_text.mn108:15.1: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned.
translation_text.mn108:15.2: These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.
translation_text.mn108:16.1: They’re content with robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
translation_text.mn108:17.1: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
translation_text.mn108:18.1: They wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again; materializing and dematerializing; going unobstructed through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful. They control the body as far as the realm of divinity.
translation_text.mn108:19.1: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.
translation_text.mn108:20.1: They understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with their own mind.
translation_text.mn108:20.2: They understand mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’,
translation_text.mn108:20.3: and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed’.
translation_text.mn108:20.17: They understand unfreed mind as ‘unfreed mind’.
translation_text.mn108:21.1: They recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn108:22.1: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn108:23.1: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn108:23.2: These are the ten inspiring things explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn108:23.3: We honor anyone in whom these things are found, and rely on them.”
translation_text.mn108:24.1: When he had spoken, Vassakāra addressed General Upananda,
translation_text.mn108:24.3: Do these venerables honor, respect, revere, and venerate those who are worthy?”
translation_text.mn108:24.5: For if these venerables were not to honor, respect, revere, and venerate them,
translation_text.mn108:25.4: “I hope the Bamboo Grove is delightful, quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat?”
translation_text.mn108:25.5: “Indeed it is, brahmin. And it is like that owing to such protectors and guardians as yourself.”
translation_text.mn108:25.6: “Surely, worthy Ānanda, it is owing to the good fellows who meditate, making a habit of meditating.
translation_text.mn108:25.7: For the good fellows do in fact meditate and make a habit of meditating.
translation_text.mn108:25.8: This one time, worthy Ānanda, worthy Gotama was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
translation_text.mn108:25.9: So I went there to see him.
translation_text.mn108:25.10: And there he spoke about meditation in many ways.
translation_text.mn108:25.11: He meditated, and made a habit of meditating.
translation_text.mn108:25.12: And he praised all kinds of meditation.”
translation_text.mn108:26.1: “No, brahmin, the Buddha did not praise all kinds of meditation, nor did he dispraise all kinds of meditation.
translation_text.mn108:26.2: And what kind of meditation did he not praise?
translation_text.mn108:26.3: It’s when someone’s heart is overcome and mired in sensual desire, and they don’t truly understand the escape from sensual desire that has arisen.
translation_text.mn108:26.4: Hiding sensual desire within, they meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate.
translation_text.mn108:26.5: Their heart is overcome and mired in ill will …
translation_text.mn108:26.11: doubt, and they don’t truly know and see the escape from doubt that has arisen.
translation_text.mn108:26.12: Hiding doubt within, they meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate.
translation_text.mn108:26.13: The Buddha didn’t praise this kind of meditation.
translation_text.mn108:27.1: And what kind of meditation did he praise?
translation_text.mn108:27.2: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn108:27.3: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn108:27.4: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.mn108:27.5: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.mn108:27.6: The Buddha praised this kind of meditation.”
translation_text.mn108:28.1: “Well, worthy Ānanda, it seems that worthy Gotama criticized the kind of meditation that deserves criticism and praised that deserving of praise.
translation_text.mn108:28.2: Well, now, worthy Ānanda, I must go.
translation_text.mn108:28.3: I have many duties, and much to do.”
translation_text.mn108:28.5: Then Vassakāra the brahmin, having approved and agreed with what Venerable Ānanda said, got up from his seat and left.
translation_text.mn108:29.1: Soon after he had left, Moggallāna the Guardian said to Ānanda,
translation_text.mn108:29.2: “Worthy Ānanda, you still haven’t answered my question.”
translation_text.mn108:29.4: ‘There is no single mendicant who has all the same qualities in each and every way as possessed by the worthy Gotama, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn108:29.5: For the Blessed One gave rise to the unarisen path, gave birth to the unborn path, and explained the unexplained path. He is the knower of the path, the discoverer of the path, the expert on the path.
translation_text.mn108:29.6: And now the disciples live following the path; they acquire it later.’”
